document_title: Ovarian functional cysts: Causes, signs and treatments
subsection_content:
Most cases of functional ovarian cysts are detected through routine gynecological examinations or ultrasound during pregnancy. When a functional cyst is detected, the doctor will prescribe monitoring within 1-2 months to see if the cyst disappears on its own or not. If the cyst disappears, you do not need any treatment intervention.
On the contrary, if monitored after 1-2 months the cyst size remains unchanged, plus symptoms and risk factors for the disease, the doctor will prescribe clinical and paraclinical examination to determine Accurate diagnosis results, avoiding mistakenly ignoring small signs that affect the diagnosis results.
The doctor will assign the patient to perform clinical and paraclinical examinations to obtain the most accurate diagnosis. Clinical diagnosis In addition to exploiting information about risk factors such as personal medical history , hereditary family diseases, etc. The doctor will ask about the symptoms you have such as: Disturbed menstrual cycle; Symptoms of pain and discomfort in the pelvic area; Feeling pain every time you have sex; Urinary habits and symptoms such as urinary retention, difficulty urinating, and constipation. Paraclinical diagnosis The doctor may prescribe paraclinical tests, including: Ultrasound to determine the location, shape, size and properties inside the cyst. Ultrasound images will also help suggest whether the tumor is benign or malignant. CT scan or MRI is indicated for larger cysts to provide more accurate results, and CT scan helps determine the extent of spread and metastasis of the cyst. Testing for traces of tumor to find signs of malignancy of cysts such as CA-125, HE4, AFP... How to treat functional ovarian cysts Dr. Kim Ngan said, functional ovarian cysts do not need to be With treatment, the cyst will disappear on its own after a few menstrual cycles. Patients are asked to monitor the growth of the cyst with repeat ultrasounds after menstruation. Patients can treat the disease using internal medicine (using medicine). However, in cases where cysts cause dangerous complications, immediate intervention is needed. Medical treatment The doctor will ask the patient to monitor the development of the cyst for about 1-2 months. After that time, if the size of the cyst does not decrease and symptoms begin to appear, the doctor may prescribe the patient to use some of the following medications: Pain relievers: Reduce pain caused by the tumor compressing the muscles. surrounding agencies. Birth control pills: Prevent ovulation, thereby reducing the risk of new cyst formation as well as limiting the increase in cyst size. Note, you need to consult your doctor for appropriate dosage instructions and instructions. Absolutely do not use medicine without a doctor's prescription. Surgical treatment of functional cysts In cases where functional cysts cause pain but do not respond to medical treatment, the doctor will prescribe the patient to have surgery to remove the cyst. Laparoscopic surgery: Currently a trusted method in cyst removal surgery because it causes less pain for the patient, less hospital stay, and quick recovery. This method is indicated in cases where the cyst is not too large, not too sticky, not suspected of malignancy or in cases of breast cancer where oophorectomy is indicated. Laparotomy: In cases where the patient has high risk factors, the cyst is large in size and has an unusual shape, the doctor will prescribe laparotomy to observe the tumor and promptly treat it if it occurs. malignant tumor. However, this method requires more recovery time. At the same time, the patient will be asked to be hospitalized for a few days before and after surgery to facilitate monitoring and examination. Laparoscopic surgery to treat ovarian cysts is preferred because it causes less pain, quick recovery time, and less hospitalization. Measures to prevent functional ovarian cysts are recommended by Dr. Kim Ngan, although not recommended. Is there any way to prevent functional ovarian cysts, but women can detect them early, monitor them and treat them effectively if they comply with regular gynecological examinations every 6 months. At the same time, women need to "listen" to their bodies, pay attention to abnormalities in the menstrual cycle each month including cycle time, menstrual symptoms... for early detection, effective treatment, and avoidance. dangerous complications.
